_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

This document was developed to comply with the United States Environmental Protection 
Agency¿s (USEPA¿s) Risk Management Program (RMP), under Section 112(r) of the Clean 
Air Act (CAA) Amendments of 1990, 40 CFR Part 68. Because New Braunfels Utility (NBU) 
facilities contain quantities of regulated toxic substances above the threshold quantities, it is 
subject to the RMP regulations.
 
Facilities

NBU is responsible for both potable water and wastewater treatment in a certified service 
area in the general vicinity of the city limits of New Braunfels, Texas. NBU operates one 
surface water treatment plant and six wells for potable water treatment and three municipal 
wastewater treatment plants.
 
Currently, the NBU Kuehler North Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) stores both 
chlorine and sulfur dioxide in up to three, one-ton containers. The NBU Kuehler South 
WWTP stores both chlorine and sulfur dioxide in up to four, one-ton containers. The 
quantity of chlorine and sulfur dioxide stored onsite exceeds the EPA¿s threshold of 2,500 
pounds and 5,000 pounds, respectively, thus subjecting Kuehler WWTPs to the RMP Rule. 
The RMP primarily consists of the following three elements: Offsite Hazard Assessment, 
Accident Prevention Program, and an Emergency Response Program.

Applicable Program Level

The RMP regulations define three Program levels based on the relative potential for public 
impacts of a process, the level of effort needed to prevent accidents, and coverage by other 
regulations. The Program levels are defined as follows:

Program 1:  Process with no public receptors within the distance to an endpoint from a 
worst-case scenario and with no accidents with offsite consequences within the past five 
years.
Program 2:  Process not eligible for Program 1 or subject to Program 3.
Program 3:  Process not eligible for Program 1 and subject to OSHA¿s PSM standard under 
federal or state OSHA programs.

Th

e Kuehler WWTPs chlorine and dechlorination processes worst case scenarios will impact 
offsite receptors and the State of Texas does not fall under the OSHA PSM standard. 
Therefore, the chlorine and dechlorination processes fall under Program 2. The RMP 
developed for the Kuehler WWTPs follows requirements of a Program 2 process.

Offsite Hazard Assessment

An offsite hazard assessment was conducted for the Kuehler WWTPs to determine the 
distance a toxic concentration of chlorine gas and sulfur dioxide gas would travel in the 
event of a release. The toxic endpoint concentration for chlorine and sulfur dioxide is three 
parts per million (ppm). The population within the radius of the release and sensitive 
receptors such as hospitals, schools, and state parks were identified. Two release scenarios¿
the ¿Worst Case¿ and an ¿Alternative Case¿ were considered. The Hazard Assessment also 
includes a five-year accident history of the Kuehler WWTPs.

Worst Case Scenario

The worst case scenario assumes the entire contents of the largest single container are 
released, regardless of how improbable that may be, over a period of ten minutes. 
Therefore, the Kuehler WWTPs must model offsite impacts of a 2,000-pound chlorine and 
sulfur dioxide release over a duration of 10 minutes. The resulting release rate is 200 pounds 
per minute. The worst case scenario also requires conservative meteorological conditions. A 
relatively slow wind speed of 1.5 meters per second and a stability class F must be assumed. 
Stability classes are categorized by the amount of turbulence in the atmosphere. Class F is 
the lowest turbulence classification. With low wind speed and atmospheric turbulence, the 
chlorine plume will dilute slowly, causing an increased distance to the toxic endpoint. 

Furthermore, only ¿passive¿ mitigation methods such as buildings or dikes can be 
considered. Passive mitigation, as defined, requires no mechanical, electrical, or human

input. The one-ton containers of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the Kuehler WWTP are not 
located inside a building and therefore cannot consider building mitigation.

EPA¿s RMP*CompTM was used  to predict the distance required for a plume of chlorine and 
sulfur dioxide gas in a worst case scenario situation to dilute to 3 ppm. Using the predicted 
distance, potential offsite public and environmental receptors were determined.

Alternative Release Scenario

The alternative release scenario reflects a type of release that is more likely to occur 
compared to the worst case scenario. Unlike the worst case scenario, the alternative release 
scenario may consider ¿active¿ mitigation such as automatic shutoff valves and scrubbers. 
Active mitigation is defined as requiring mechanical, electrical, or human input. 
Furthermore, the alternative release scenario assumes more realistic regional and seasonal 
meteorology as compared to the worst case scenario. 

The alternative release scenario modeled for the Kuehler WWTPs involves a one-ton 
chlorine container rupture due to dropping it during changing out empty containers with 
full containers. This particular scenario was selected because it represents a ¿worst case¿ 
alternative release resulting in offsite impacts.

EPA¿s RMP*CompTM was used to predict the distance required for the plume of chlorine gas 
in a alternative release scenario to dilute to 3 ppm. Using the predicted distance, potential 
offsite public and environmental receptors were determined.

Five-year Accident History

Under the RMP Rule, a five-year accident release history must be reported for regulated 
substances exceeding the threshold quantity. The release must have caused at least one of 
the following situations: onsite or offsite death(s), injuries, or significant property damage, 
offsite environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. There were no reportable 
accidents at the Kuehler WWTPs between Jun

e 21, 1999, and the present date.

Prevention Program

The Prevention Program is composed of Safety Information, Hazard Review, Operating 
Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Incident Investigation, and Compliance Audit 
procedures. The procedures are designed to prevent an accidental release.

Safety Information

Information regarding process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment is 
compiled and included in the Prevention Program as a resource to emergency response 
planners and to develop training programs and operating procedures. Within the Safety 
Information section, one can find comprehensive chemical data including action thresholds, 
health hazards, chemical exposure limitations, and physical properties. In addition, details 
such as maximum intended inventory and safe upper and lower operating limits can be 
found.

Hazard Review

The hazard review (HR) provides information that will assist Kuehler WWTPs staff in 
making decisions for improving safety and reducing the consequences of hazardous 
accidental releases. A HR is a systematic effort to evaluate potential causes and 
consequences of accidental releases. The HR focuses on equipment, instrumentation, 
utilities, human actions, and external factors that might affect the process. Several 
improvements to the Kuehler WWTP facility were recommended as a result of the hazard 
review.

Operating Procedures

A copy of the Kuehler WWTPs operating procedures is included in the RMP. These 
procedures are designed to ensure continuous, efficient, and safe operation of the facility. 
The operating procedures are also used to train new employees and to provide refresher 
training for existing staff.

Training

The USEPA requires that a training program be included as part of the RMP. An effective 
training program can significantly reduce the number and severity of accidental release 
incidents. The Kuehler WWTP RMP includes guidelines for conducting regular

and 
structured plant training. Training record forms are included with the program for 
documentation purposes. Elements of the program include training in safety information, 
operating procedures, maintenance, and emergency response procedures.

Maintenance

Maintenance ensures equipment used to process, store, or handle chlorine and sulfur 
dioxide are functioning properly and installed to minimize the risk of releases. An effective 
maintenance program is one of the primary lines of defense against a release and addresses 
equipment testing and inspection, preventive maintenance schedules, and personnel 
training. When implemented, a regular maintenance program ensures that process 
equipment performs properly and that documentation exists to support reliable, safe 
operation and maintenance of the process.

Incident Investigation

An incident investigation program has been developed that outlines the investigation team, 
investigation process, and implementation of changes. Ultimately, it is desired that the staff 
learn from incidents and act to prevent similar incidents in the future. Necessary forms for 
documentation are included and must be maintained for a minimum of five years after each 
incident.

Compliance Audit

Procedures were developed to complete a compliance audit for the Kuehler WWTP. A 
compliance audit is a self-evaluation of the effectiveness of the RMP program that identifies 
deficiencies, assures corrective action, and increases safety awareness among plant staff. To 
ensure compliance with the program, the RMP includes a checklist that the Kuehler WWTP 
staff must complete at least once every three years. The program manager of RMP for NBU 
must certify that the RMP team has evaluated compliance with provisions of the program, 
and verify that the procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed. Audit 
report forms are provided, the two most recent of which must always be maintained (older

ones can be discarded).

Emergency Response Program

The Emergency Response Program develops a plan for dealing with a release. Currently, the 
Kuehler WWTP is a non-responding facility and relies on the New Braunfels Fire 
Department to respond to all substantial releases. The Kuehler WWTP is also included in 
the Comal County City Emergency Management Plan developed under the Emergency 
Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA). 
If in the future, if NBU decides to take further action to stop a release, an emergency 
response program consisting of an emergency response plan, emergency response 
equipment procedures, employee training, and procedures to ensure the program is up-to-
date must be developed.

Management System

A management system was developed to oversee implementation of the RMP elements. The 
management system assigned the NBU Executive Director of Water Utilities as the position 
with the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the 
RMP elements. Additionally, it defined the lines of authority so that NBU staff understand 
their individual responsibilities to implement the RMP elements on an ongoing basis and 
how to communicate the procedures outlined in the program.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

While developing the RMP for the Kuehler WWTP, several deficiencies were noted.  These 
were compiled, along with other mitigative recommendations, and evaluation and 
implementation responsibility was assigned to each item. The full list can be found in 
Section 2 of the RMP, ¿Hazard Review¿.
